6  The district court also determined that McDonoughโs malicious prosecution claim was timely because it had not 
  accrued until his acquittal. That claim is still proceeding in the district court as to other Defendants. 
 
7  At times, McDonough characterizes the fabrication of evidence claim against Smith as a conspiracy to fabricate 
  evidence with other Defendants. That does not affect our conclusion as to the accrual of that claim. 
 
8  District courts in this Circuit have followed Veal and concluded that a ยง 1983 claim based on fabricated evidence 
  โaccrues when the plaintiff learns or should have learned that the evidence was fabricated and such conduct causes 
the claimant some injury.โ Mitchell v. Home, 377 F.Supp.2d 361, 373 (S.D.N.Y. 2005) 
 
9  McDonough does not allege that fabricated evidence was used against him in the second trial that was not 
  presented in the first. 
 
10  The elements of a malicious prosecution claim require a plaintiff to establish that โ(1) the defendant initiated a 
  prosecution against [the] plaintiff, (2) without probable cause to believe the proceeding can succeed, (3) the 
proceeding was begun with malice and, (4) the matter terminated in plaintiffโs favor.โ Ricciuti, 124 F.3d at 130. The 
elements are the same for the New York tort and the constitutional one. See id.; Colon v. City of New York, 60 N.Y.2d 
78, 82, 468 N.Y.S.2d 453, 455 N.E.2d 1248 (1983). 
 
11  The district court, however, concluded that Smith was entitled to absolute immunity from the malicious prosecution 
  claim. That decision is addressed later in this opinion. 
 
12  As one district court in this Circuit aptly explained: โA right to a fair trial claim is distinct from a malicious 
  prosecution claim.โ Bailey v. City of New York, 79 F.Supp.3d 424, 446 (E.D.N.Y. 2015) (emphasis added). 
 
13  The Supreme Court in Wallace stated that there may be circumstances where the district court might exercise its 
  discretion to stay the civil action until the criminal case is resolved, but that is not relevant here. Wallace, 549 U.S. at 
7 
 

 
 
McDonough v. Smith, 898 F.3d 259 (2018)   
 
 
393โ94, 127 S.Ct. 1091. 
 
14  We are also not persuaded by McDonoughโs reliance on the Supreme Courtโs recent decision in Manuel v. City of 
  Joliet, Ill., which held that a plaintiff (formerly a criminal defendant) may seek damages under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 
concerning his pretrial detention on the ground that it violated the Fourth Amendment for the period of pretrial 
detention after his arrest. โโโ U.S. โโโโ, 137 S.Ct. 911, 914, 197 L.Ed.2d 312 (2017). That a claim under the Fourth 
Amendment may be based on events occurring after an arrest does not affect our conclusion that McDonoughโs due 
process claim accrued well before his acquittal, and the Supreme Court stated in Manuel that its recognition that 
the Fourth Amendment applies to a period after the arrest did not necessarily alter the accrual date of that and 
other causes of action, and left the question for the Courts of Appeals to resolve. Id. at 922. 
 
15  McDonough also asserts on appeal that Smithโs appointment as Special District Attorney was invalid under New 
  York law and that the conduct McDonough was charged with in the indictment could not meet the elements of the 
various state criminal statutes. In order to strip Smith of his absolute prosecutorial immunity, McDonough would be 
required to show Smith proceeded despite a โclear absence of all jurisdictionโ for the prosecution. Barr v. Abrams, 
810 F.2d 358, 361 (2d Cir. 1987). He has not done so. Also, as to the claim that Smith was not properly appointed, 
the correct forum for such a claim would be in the New York courts. In Working Families Party v. Fisher, 23 N.Y.3d 
539, 992 N.Y.S.2d 172, 15 N.E.3d 1181 (2014), the New York Court of Appeals held that the method for challenging 
the appointment of a special prosecutor is through a N.Y. C.P.L.R. Article 78 proceeding. McDonough did not pursue 
the Article 78 course to invalidate Smithโs appointment. Rather, McDonough alleged in his complaint that he sought 
to have Smith disqualified by petitioning the County to file an action in the state courts to nullify Smithโs 
appointment, and later filing a motion in his criminal case to dismiss the charges on the basis that Smithโs 
appointment was unlawful. That motion was denied. As to the claim concerning the New York criminal statutes, the 
appropriate forum for challenging the application of the state criminal statutes to McDonoughโs alleged conduct 
was in McDonoughโs two state criminal trials, not during this subsequent civil action under ยง 1983. To the extent he 
argues that this should support his malicious prosecution claim, the argument does not affect Smithโs absolute 
immunity for his prosecutorial conduct, as it is the heartland of such a protection. See Imbler v. Pachtman, 424 U.S. 
409, 430โ31, 96 S.Ct. 984, 47 L.Ed.2d 128 (1976) (holding that absolute immunity protects prosecutors for their 
conduct โintimately associated with the judicial phase of the criminal process ....โ). 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
8

2  In accepting the Court of Appealsโ treatment of McDonoughโs claim as one sounding in denial of due process, we 
  express no view as to what other constitutional provisions (if any) might provide safeguards against the creation or 
use of fabricated evidence enforceable through a 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 action. See Soldal v. Cook County, 506 U.S. 56, 70, 
113 S.Ct. 538, 121 L.Ed.2d 450 (1992) (โCertain wrongs affect more than a single right and, accordingly, can 
implicate more than one of the Constitutionโs commandsโ). Moreover, because the Second Circuit understood 
McDonoughโs due process claim to allege a deprivation of liberty, we have no occasion to consider the proper 
handling of a fabricated-evidence claim founded on an allegation that the use of fabricated evidence was so 
egregious as to shock the conscience, see, e.g., County of Sacramento v. Lewis, 523 U.S. 833, 849, 118 S.Ct. 1708, 
140 L.Ed.2d 1043 (1998), or caused harms exclusively to โinterests other than the interest in freedom from physical 
restraint,โ Albright v. Oliver, 510 U.S. 266, 283, 114 S.Ct. 807, 127 L.Ed.2d 114 (1994) (Kennedy, J., concurring in 
judgment); see also, e.g., W. Keeton, D. Dobbs, R. Keeton, & D. Owen, Prosser and Keeton on Law of Torts ยง 119, p. 
870 (5th ed. 1984) (Prosser & Keeton) (โ[O]ne who is wrongfully prosecuted may suffer both in reputation and by 
confinementโ). Accordingly, we do not address what the accrual rule would be for a claim rooted in other types of 
harm independent of a liberty deprivation, as no such claim is before us. See 898 F.3d 259, 266 (CA2 2018). 
 
3  The Second Circuit borrowed the common-law elements of malicious prosecution to govern McDonoughโs distinct

defined the elements of such a ยง 1983 claim, see Manuel v. Joliet, 580 U. S. โโโโ, โโโโ โ โโโโ, 137 S.Ct. 911, 
921โ922, 197 L.Ed.2d 312 (2017), and this case provides no occasion to opine on what the elements of a 
constitutional malicious prosecution action under ยง 1983 are or how they may or may not differ from those of a 
fabricated-evidence claim. Similarly, while noting that only McDonoughโs malicious prosecution claim was barred on 
absolute-immunity grounds below, we make no statement on whether or how the doctrine of absolute immunity 
would apply to McDonoughโs fabricated-evidence claim. Any further consideration of that question is properly 
addressed by the Second Circuit on remand, subject to ordinary principles of waiver and forfeiture.

5  Smith urges the Court to steer away from the comparison to malicious prosecution, noting that the Second Circuit

tort; comparing constitutional and common-law torts is not a one-to-one matching exercise. See, e.g., Heck, 512 U.S. 
at 479, 484, 114 S.Ct. 2364 (analogizing malicious prosecution to several distinct claims). Tellingly, Smith has not 
suggested an alternative common-law analogy. See Tr. of Oral Arg. 44โ46.

10  Because McDonoughโs acquittal was unquestionably a favorable termination, we have no occasion to address the

not the question before us.
